choices.B: The IPv6 traffic for nse8user is filtered using the DNS profile.
choices.A: The IPv4 policy is allowing security profile groups.
choices.C: The IPv4 traffic for nse8user is filtered using the DNS profile.
choices.D: The Web traffic for nse8user is being filtered differently in IPv4 and IPv6.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
I think CD

choices.B: The high-risk file will go to the system quarantine.
choices.A: The high-risk file will be discarded by attachment analysis.
choices.D: The high-risk file will be discarded by malware/virus outbreak protection.
choices.C: The high-risk file will be received by the recipient.

discussion.content:
C is correct
Under FortiSandbox, set the default Scan mode: Submit and wait for result to wait for scan results before delivering the email, or Submit only to submit emails to FortiSandbox and still deliver the email without waiting for the scan results.
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortimail/6.2.3/cookbook/497262/creating-an-antivirus-profile

Selected Answer: C
Sandbox is Submit only

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C. FortiSandbox is set to "Submit only", so the action specified on High Risk will not execute. Can't be D, because if it got to Sandbox inspection, it already passed Malware/virus outbreak. Also, the default action is set to SystemQuarantine.

questions.question_text:
You are asked to add a FortiDDoS to the network to combat detected slow connection attacks such as Slowloris.
Which prevention mode on FortiDDoS will protect you against this specific type of attack?

choices.D: The changed configuration on the FortiGate will be overwritten in favor of what is on the FortiManager the next time that the device configuration is pushed.
choices.B: The changed configuration on the FortiGate will remain the next time that the device configuration is pushed from FortiManager.
choices.C: The device configuration was changed on both the local FortiGate side and the FortiManager side; auto-update is disabled.
choices.A: The device configuration was changed on the local FortiGate side only; auto-update is disabled.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
CD seems correct, especially C - If auto-update is disabled and changes are done on both FGT and FMG then the device level DB will be different from revision DB on FGT. https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortimanager/7.2.0/administration-guide/229356/auto-update-and-auto-retrieve

C is only correct, if you ignore the last part "auto update is disbaled" Unless you view it as "there have been changes at both side, so to prevent issues, FMG disabled auto update until the next push happenes"

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

You log into FortiManager, access the Device Manager window and notice that one of the managed devices is not in normal status.
Referring to the exhibit, which two statements correctly describe the status and result of the affected device? (Choose two.)

A company has just deployed a new FortiMail in gateway mode. The administrator is asked to strengthen e-mail protection by applying the policies shown below.
"¢ E-mails can only be accepted if a valid e-mail account exists.
"¢ Only authenticated users can send e-mails out.
Which two actions will satisfy the requirements? (Choose two.)
